PI1. Solid transboundary and cross-sectoral governance arrangements in place PI1. comment.narrative: Substantial gaps & weaknesses in governance arrangements, identified under the CLME Project (GEF ID 1032) Technical proposal for a Regional Governance Framework (RGF) Politically endorsed 10-year CLME+ SAP, shaped on the RGF proposal For more details on the baseline: see Project Document Section 1 as well as the COMPONENT 1 Outputs Baseline analysis and technical proposal for multi-level, nested RGF Regionally endorsed SAP presents roadmap towards enhanced coordination & cooperation arrangements With the exception of Brazil, all CLME+ countries can become signatories to the Cartagena Convention and its Protocols. At the 15th IGM of the Caribbean Environment Programme (CEP) Member States encouraged the Secretariat to explore opportunities and needs for collaboration with Brazil in areas of relevance to the Convention and its Protocols Contracting Parties to the Cartagena Convention have requested the Secretariat to explore opportunities for greater integration between the LBS and SPAW Protocol Work Programmes Three Regional Fisheries Bodies (RFBs) exist within the CLME+; 2 of these (OSPESCA, CRFM) have formal mandate for all policy cycle components but are sub-regional only; WECAFC covers full region but has no associated high-level formal/binding decision-making mechanism. MoU between CRFM and OSPESCA, established during the CLME Project No formally established “CLME+ SAP implementation” coordination mechanism; informal acceptance that SAP/CLME+ ProDoc Core Development Team membership can provide the initial (expandable) basis for this mechanism Consensus has not been achieved to date regarding a permanent policy coordination mechanism for sLMR in the CLME+ Region A variety of mechanisms exists, in a sub-set of the CLME+ countries; not all mechanisms are, or have been sustainable in time Some success stories of inter-sectoral coordination under the CLME Project; in many cases inter-sectoral coordination is still sub-optimal Lack of in-depth analysis and g

T.PI5. (Milestone) Interim mechanism to support coordinated SAP implementation , established by end of PY1; (Target) Institutional arrangement(s) and operational mechanism to coordinate SAP implementation efforts beyond project life span, consolidated before PE. T.PI2. Regional Strategy and Action Plan for key marine habitats covers at least 50% of CLME+ countries, by end of PY3

During the reporting period the CLME+ project objective is on track to be fully achieved by the end of the project. During the virtual CLME+ Project Steering Committee (PSC) Meeting which took place 16-18 June 2020, the CLME+ Project Coordination Unit, provided the PSC with an update on CLME+ Project technical and financial implementation as of May 2020. It was noted that 46.5% of milestones and targets under Components 1,2, 4 and 5 had been fully met from the start of the project to now (Annex 35) (caution is called on by the reader in interpreting this percentage as it does not account for the substantive progress that has been made towards the other targets). This was an increase from the same time last year. The remaining targets are in progress and most are anticipated to be met by the end of 2020. In total 4 outputs, (O1.2, 2.3, 2.4, and 2.6) under Components 1,2, 4 and 5 have been successfully delivered. Notwithstanding, some delays were being experienced with some outputs. The analysis further noted that under Component 3, three of the sub projects were near completion or completed (Outputs 3.1, 3.3 and 3.5) whilst 2 were experiencing delays (Outputs 3.2 and 3.4).
At the time of the 2020 PIR, which is expected to be the last for this project, not all Project targets have been met. Many of the remaining targets are expected to be met by 31 December 2020. In light of this, Annex 84 provides the reader with all deliverables under the project. This Annex will continue to be updated until the end of the UNDP/GEF CLME+ Project and as such will have all final versions of project deliverables.
Financially the analysis showed substantial financial implementation progress, from 51% of budget disbursed in 2019 to 80% budget disbursed by end of May 2020. Notwithstanding the increase in budget disbursed, the analysis also noted that the existing global pandemic would not have allowed the remaining budget to successfully be executed within the, then, existing timeline of the CLME+ Project. Taking into account the delays experienced with technical implementation and the risk associated with the remaining budget, within the Project timeline, the CLME+ Project Coordination Unit recommended amendments to the milestones and targets in the Project Results Framework (Annex 36), and also shared a revised budget and timeline for the consideration of the PSC. In light of the foregoing, the CLME+ Project Steering Committee, during the June 2020 meeting, approved a 3-month extension of the project duration until 31 July 2021. They also approved the revised work plan and budget, including the amendments to the CLME+ Project Results Framework (Annex 6) Advancements with all 5 of the CLME+ components were observed at the end of June 2020, when compared to the same time last year. Approximately 58% of milestones and targets under component 1 were successfully implemented to date. One of the project’s flagship target, consensus on the Coordination Mechanism for enhanced ocean governance in the CLME+ region -meant to facilitate and support EBM and EAF- was successfully achieved during this reporting period. Component 2 saw approximately 57% successful achievements of milestones and targets to date. Three of the outputs under component 3 (60%) have been successfully achieved. Component 4 has been the least advanced with 25% of milestones and targets met to date. However, the Fisheries Investment Plans have been developed and the integrated Pollution and Habitat Investment Plans are being developed and are expected to be finalized by the end of 2020. Approximately 52% of milestones and targets under Component 5 have been successfully achieved to date. Taking into account the revised work plan, 3 month no-cost extension, and the advancements to the project outcomes, including the fact a number of flagship targets have been met and that many of the remaining project targets are expected to be achieved by the end of 2020, (no less than 80% of targets met) the CLME+ PCU, while flagging the transformational nature of several of the projects achievements to date, is confident of the successful achievement of the Project’s Development Objective by the end of the CLME+ Project. During this reporting period progress is ongoing towards solid transboundary and cross-sectoral governance arrangements and to put in place a Multi-level, nested Regional Governance Framework for sLMR, in-line with the endorsed CLME+ SAP,. Fifty-eight per cent of milestones and targets under this Outcome have been successfully achieved to date with the remaining showing good progress to be met by the end of 2020. One of the main CLME+ Project flagship targets under this Component, which includes consensus on the Coordination Mechanism was achieved during this reporting period and can be seen as transformational in moving the region away from a silo approach to ocean governance, and puts the region at the forefront of global efforts to achieve better collaboration between Regional Seas Programmes, Regional Fisheries Bodies, and LME Programmes and Projects. The Sustainable Financing Plan (Annex 11, section 5) for the Coordination Mechanism was also developed and submitted during this reporting period. Other milestones and targets under this Component are on track to be successfully completed within the projected timeline. An overview of the specific achievements are defined below: Output 1.1 Decisions on coordination & cooperation arrangements and institutional mandates, in line with SAP Strategies 1 (environment), 2 (fisheries) and 3 (cross-sectoral policy coordination) 1. T.PI1Formal agreement between Brazil and the Cartagena Convention Secretariat for the coordination of actions relevant to the Convention and its Protocols, in place by end of project and subject to mutual priorities and interest (opportunistic) Although areas of cooperation were agreed between the Government of Brazil and the Cartagena Convention Secretariat, and a draft MOU (Annex 1) was developed and shared with the Government of Brazil for review, no further advancements have been observed within the last year. Whilst no major efforts will be placed on advancing this by the Cartagena Convention Secretariat, they have indicated commitment to advance if interest is expressed by the Government of Brazil. 2. 2. T.PI2 (Milestone) Decision on a modality for the coordination of actions under the SPAW and LBS Protocols, at Cartagena Convention COP 13 (2014); (Target) Roadmap for collaborative action on SPAW and LBS available by end of first quarter of 2017 Milestone and Target met. First ever joint Scientific Technical Advisory Committee (STAC) Meetings of the LBS and SPAW Protocols under the Cartagena Convention successfully held in 4th quarter of 2016. A Roadmap for Collaborative Action on SPAW and LBS elaborated and endorsed at the 17 Intergovernmental Meeting of the Cartagena Convention (Annex 2) . Efforts also materialized to integrate, for the first time ever, meetings of the Contracting Parties for both Protocols (SPAW/ LBS) during the convening of the 15th COP of the Cartagena Convention in Honduras (June 2019). This enabled Contracting Parties of the Convention to attend the COPs of the two Protocols concurrently. Another joint STAC is planned for the final quarter of 2020 with support from the new ACP MEA Phase 3 Project. 3. T.PI3 Decision among CLME+ partners on the interim coordination mechanism for sustainable fisheries, by the beginning of 2016 Target Met. The Interim Coordination Mechanism (ICM) for Sustainable Fisheries was formalized through a Memorandum of Understanding (Annex 3) in January 2016 between three major Regional Fisheries Bodies (CRFM, OSPESCA and WECAFC-FAO). To date ten meetings of the interim mechanism have taken place, and the activities and achievements of the mechanism are being published on the CLME+ Hub please refer to link for information on the meeting summaries https://tinyurl.com/y6lqlj6d. 4. T.PI4 (Milestone) Feasibility analysis (technical & economic feasibility, and political & social acceptance) of different region-wide governance arrangements for sustainable fisheries, available by July 2017; (Target) Further CLME+ Project support provided to the process towards a multi-country decision on a robust, region-wide governance arrangement for sustainable, ecosystem-based fisheries management for the CLME+ region till project end, being cognizant of the independent timeline of the regional governance processes of the involved RFBs; The Western Central Atlantic Fisheries Commission (WECAFC) reorientation process which is referenced in the CLME+ SAP under strategy 1 is under development and several actions have been taken with member countries and internally in order to catalyse the process. The CLME+ Project is providing financial support to FAO to assist with the reorientation process. The First WECAFC Preparatory Meeting for the reorientation of WECAFC was held in Bridgetown, Barbados, 25-26 March 2019. The summary report of the Preparatory Meeting (Annex 37) was presented for review and endorsement at the 17th Session of the WECAFC that took place in Miami, USA, 15-18 July 2019. Member states endorsed the conclusions of the 1st Preparatory Meeting for the WECAFC reorientation process towards a more effective and viable arrangement (Annex 4). The next steps include a review of experiences by similar entities and arrangements, and discussing the most adequate system for the region. Members agreed on Terms of Reference for an Inter-Sessional Working Group that will review and provide options and recommendations for a 2nd Preparatory Meeting scheduled to take place by end of 2020. 5. T.PI5 (Milestone) Interim mechanism to support coordinated SAP implementation , formally established by end of first half of 2017; (Target) Institutional arrangement(s) and operational mechanism to coordinate integrated ocean governance (incl. continued SAP implementation) efforts beyond project life span, consolidated before end of 2020 Milestone met SAP ICM formally established with 8 IGOs (UNEP, FAO, UNESCO-IOC, CCAD, OSPESCA, CRFM, CARICOM Secretariat and OECS Commission) signing a MOU for enhanced cooperation and coordination by end of 2017 (Annex 5). Through this, the CLME+ Project is pioneering collaboration among Regional Seas, Regional Fisheries Bodies and LME initiatives, and the CLME+ SAP ICM has been showcased as “best practice” at a variety of fora around the World, To date, 7 meetings of the SAP ICM ( Oct 15, Sep 16, May 17, Aug 18, Aug 19, Sep 20, May 20) (Annex 38) have taken place, and continuity of ICM work beyond the project end is being planned for through the identification of a step-wise process towards the creation of the long-term Coordination Mechanism. (Target) This target has been partially met with the decision on the Coordination Mechanism during the last CLME+ Project Steering Committee in June 2020 (Annexes 6 and 7) and is expected to be fully met by the end of the 2020. 6. T.PI6 (Target A) Consensus among CLME+-participating countries on a permanent, inclusive and sustainably financed coordination mechanism for sLRM governance, by the end of 2020 (Target B) Submission of the mechanism to countries of the CLME+ region for adoption, as soon as Target A is achieved. Target A Met. The CLME+ Project Steering Committee (PSC) during a virtual Meeting held 16-18 June 2020 endorsed the core aspects (objective, scope, structure and functions) of the Coordination Mechanism (Annexes 6 and 7). They also agreed (Annex 7) that a Memorandum of Understanding should be used to formally establish the Coordination Mechanism; the CLME+ PCU’s proposed process and timeline towards the creation and operationalization of the Coordination Mechanism was also acknowledged by the PSC. Target B – Work continues on reviewing and revising the draft Memorandum of Understanding so that it can be shared with CLME+ countries and organisations for signature. Output 1.2 National Inter-sectoral Coordination (NIC) mechanisms (including science-policy interfaces) in place. Output achieved. 1. T.PI1 (Milestone) Completed baseline analysis of NIC mechanisms, including identification of good practices, by end of 2015 and updated by end of 2019; (Target) Sustainable NIC or equivalent mechanisms operating in at least 60% of CLME+ participating countries, by end of April 2020 Milestone and Target met NIC analysis, inclusive of best practices undertaken in 2016. A “Good Practice Guideline for successful National Intersectoral Coordination Mechanisms” (Annex 8) developed and updated in 2020. As of July 2019, it was estimated that the NICs or their equivalent are operating in more than 60% of participating CLME+ countries. Progress towards NIC establishment in the region is now also featured on the CLME+ Hub https://www.caribbeanmarineatlas.net/maps/11032/view Output 1.3 Regional policies, declarations and/or regulations, and associated national-level legislation and/or plans, are appropriate to enable effective EBM/EAF in the CLME+ 1. T.PI1 Milestone Strategy to support the mainstreaming of EBM/EAF concept and principles in policies, declarations, regulations, plans and legislation, available by end of 2017; Milestone Met Strategy to support the mainstreaming of EBM/EAF concepts and principles, declarations, regulations, plans and legislation developed and submitted to CLME+ Project Coordination Unit (Annex 9). Target A) EBM/EAF concepts and key principles integrated in at least 4 (sub)-regional policies relevant to the SAP, and in updated fisheries/environmental legislations/policies/plans in at least 60% of CLME+ countries where such updates occur between 2017 and 2020 2. First EBM/EAF baseline inventory undertaken (Annex 10). Results indicate that there is evidence supporting incremental EBM and EAF implementation in CLME+ countries. An analysis undertaken of status in the first half of 2020 show that most of the 40 states and territories assessed are making incremental progress towards the implementation of EBM/EAF at the national level. For example, in CARICOM, the countries of Belize, Jamaica, Saint Kitts and Nevis are where comprehensive EBM is being increasingly demonstrated. Within non-English-speaking locations in the CLME + region, there are also many examples of marine incremental progress in the implementation of EBM/EAF, e.g. in Bonaire (Target B) Gender and youth concerns mainstreamed and incorporated in at least 3 (sub) regional policies relevant to the SAP, by end of 2020 Ongoing, linked to target A. Expected to be met by December 2020. Output 1.4 Data management, access & exchange arrangements T.PI1. MoUs, protocols and/or other arrangements to facilitate access to/exchange of critical data sets to support SAP M&E and SOMEE reporting, available by end of project 1.T. PI1 Ongoing. The following advancements have taken place under this Output: - Incorporation of aspects related to data and information exchange, State of Marine Environment and Associated Economies (SOMEE) reporting, joint monitoring of the SAP, in the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) establishing the Interim Coordinating Mechanism (ICM) SAP CLME+ (Annex 5); MoU signed and mechanism established and active; - Incorporation of aspects related to information flow book, priority areas identified under the CLME+ SAP in the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) establishing the Interim Fisheries Coordination Mechanism (annex 3); - Data Collection Framework for the WECAFC Region adopted during the last WECAFC Session (annex 4). - Identification of best practices by UNEP-CEP, in the context of the development of State of Convention Report on Land Based Sources of Pollution (SOCAR) /SOMEE - Data Exchange Policy developed by CRFM under the Flying Fish Sub-Project, to be used as a model for data exchange policy framework to support fisheries management in CRFM countries (Annex 23 ) - Agreement on a harmonised methodology for resource assessment between OSPESCA member countries in the context of lobster fisheries (Annex 21) Output 1.5 Sustainable financing mechanism(s) to ensure short, medium and long-term operations of the sLMR governance arrangements T.PI1. (Milestone) Sustainable financing plan (proposal), incl. evaluation and comparison of options, to be delivered by end of 2019 ; (Target) Final version of the plan addresses feedback from CLME+ partners on the initial proposal and is delivered by the end of April 2020 1. T.PI1 Milestone and Target met Merged with Output 1.1. T.PI6 The Sustainable Financing Plan (Annex 11, section 5) was submitted and shared with countries in December 2019. 2. T.PI2Work is ongoing towards obtaining country endorsments of the plan, expected before end of 2020. During this reporting period progress continued with support to key organisations and stakeholder groups to allow for their effective participation in implementing knowledge-based EBM/EAF for shared living marine resources for the benefit of the people of the region. By the end of the reporting period approximately 57% of milestones and targets under this Output were met (approximately 24% increase over the same period last year). However some delays were experienced under this component. As such a revision of some of the end dates for milestones and targets were amended and approved by the CLME+ Project Steering Committee in June 2020. Notwithstanding the foregoing, it is anticipated that remaining targets under this outcome will be met by the end of 2020. Achievements under this output are outlined below: Output 2.1 Regional Action Plans for the management, conservation and sustainable use of fishery resources and for the protection of the marine environment 1. T.PI1 Target A Met. The Regional Plan of Action to Prevent, Deter and Eliminate Illegal, Unregulated and Unreported Fishing in WECAFC Member Countries (Annex 4 and 12) was endorsed by Members at the 17 Session of WECAFC in July 2019. Target B development of National Plan of Action for IUU Fishing, and expected to be delivered before the end of 2020. 2. T.PI2 Regional Strategy and Action Plan (RSAP) for the Habitats-Target partially met. Two consultative workshops have been held with stakeholders. A draft RSAP was presented via the meeting document Overview Report on the State of Marine Habitats in the Wider Caribbean & Regional Strategy and Action Plan for the Valuation, Protection and/or Restoration of Key Marine Habitats in the Wider Caribbean 2021 – 2030 and supported by SPAW COP10 Decision 14 for the Secretariat to continue “progress towards completing the draft State of Habitat and the 2020-2030 Regional Strategy and Action Plan and Investment Plan, ... for consideration at COP11 and further relevant action, taking into account the comments and inputs received by Parties and partners ...” A final draft of the Regional Strategy and Action Plan for the Valuation, Protection and/or Restoration of Key Marine Habitats in the Wider Caribbean was submitted to the CLME+ PCU for review in the second quarter of 2020 (Annex 13). 3. T.PI3 Regional Strategy and Action Plan on Nutrient Reduction: While there have been delays in the finalization of contracts for partners to facilitate full development of the Nutrients Strategy, this will unintentionally enable greater link and integration with the Regional Habitats Restoration Strategy. The activity also benefits from co-financing support associated with a new GEF Amazon Project for the implementation of their Strategic Action Programme. Despite initial delays, preliminary work has been initiated by the Secretariat with CIMAB and IMA in testing the questionnaire and communicating with countries regarding its dissemination. The report is expected to be completed by November 2020. Output 2.2 Civil Society and Private Sector Actions programmed, 1. T.PI1 Target Met People Managing Oceans (The Civil Society Action Programme for the Sustainable Management for the Shared Living Marine Resources for the Caribbean and North Brazil Shelf Large Marine Ecosystems) (Annex 14) has been developed. The CSAP has been endorsed by 35 civil society organisations (Annex 29) and is transformational in the sense of how SAPs are being dealt with in the GEF IW portfolio (to our understanding, the first LME project to deliver a dedicated civil society SAP, in addition to the main CLME+ SAP delivered under the predecessor CLME Project). T.PI2 (Target A) Private Sector/Sustainable Ocean Based Socio Economic Development Actions incorporated in at least 2 or the Regional Strategies/Action and/or Investment Plans (by end of 2020 Work is ongoing on the development of the Regional Strategies and Investment Plans and it is anticipated that this target will be fully met by the end of 2020
2. Target B Met - Direct participation of at least 5 CSO/FFO/youth organizations in concrete stress reduction/ecosystem restoration activities, across the CLME+ region, by end of April 2020 - Civil Society Organisations have been engaged in a seamoss activity in St. Kitts and Nevis (Annex 25)and a CSOs are also engaged in the North Brazil Shelf EMB sub project. Further FFOs have been engaged in all the Fisheries Sub-projects under component 3 (see component 3). 3. T.PI3 Target partially met. TORS and Workplan for Small Grants Coordination Mechanism developed by end of June 2018, and roadmap for operationalization of a Small Grants Coordination Mechanism by 31 July 2020 A Donor Roundtable for Effective support for civil society and the Caribbean and North Brazil Shelf Large Marine Ecosystems was convened in March 2018. A Concept and Workplan for the development of a Small Grants Coordination Mechanism was developed and shared with the CLME+ PCU in August 2018 (Annex 15); once operational, the mechanism will be expected to transfer the way in which the multiple Small Grants mechanisms in the region are being programmed and implemented. The concept was also discussed with donors who indicated interest in being part of the Small Grants Coordination Mechanism (Annex 16). A roadmap for operationalization of a Small Grants Coordination Mechanism should be submitted by 31 July 2020 Output 2.3 Identification of good practices for data & information management (DIM), and of best available (innovative) technologies and tools, to support communication, awareness building (CAB) and decision-making (DM) processes 1. T.PI1 Milestone Met. Innovative technologies disseminated at the 2017 GCFI Conference. A special session was included in the main agenda of the 2017 GCFI Annual Conference, (Annex 39) where a selection of innovative technologies (relevant to Data & Information Management/DIM and Decision-Making/DM) were presented to the GCFI community. Technical briefs on these solutions were delivered by the presenters.
Output 2.4 Overarching CLME+ Knowledge Management & Communication Strategy T.PI1 Target A met. First version of CLME+ Overarching Communications Strategy developed and available to all co-executing partners by end of 2016 (Annex 17) (Target B met) By end of July 2019, (updated) Knowledge Management & Communications - IW/LME LEARN provided resources to allow a consultant to undertake an assessment on “Supporting Knowledge Management (KM) and Communications activities in the GEF/UNDP CLME+ Project” (Annex 18). A number of recommendations made through the consultancy are being taken under consideration. During the last year work has advanced significantly with communications and knowledge management with the support of a communications intern. Advancements have taken place with the CLME+ Hub (clmeplus.org) and the CLME+ PCU has enhanced engagement with participating countries and partners.
Output 2.5 “Strategy” to facilitate training and capacity building of CLME+ stakeholders on issues of cross-cutting importance for the SAP Strategies 1. T.PI1 (a)Technical Task Team Established -Milestone met as per the amended targets approved by Project Steering Committee (Annex 19) Target A Met – Beta Version of the portal developed and link shared with the CLME+ PCU in 2nd quarter of 2020http://marinetraining.embrc.org/ . Work continues with the other targets under this output, although some of the target dates were amended in 2020, as a result of delays. In light of this IOC UNESCO has indicated that all remaining targets associated with this output will be completed by end of November 2020. The draft Sustainability Plan for the Training Portal is expected to be shared with the SAP ICM in September for feedback and further refinement.
Output 2.6 Targeted research agendas. Output successfully delivered. T.PI1 Target Met. Final version of the Science and Research Serving Ocean Governance in the Wider Caribbean was submitted to the CLME+ PCU at the end of the reporting period (Annex 20). The document includes three Research Agenda Chapters which focus on the three transboundary issues of unsustainable fisheries, habitat degradation and pollution. Research priorities identified by decision makers are outlined in these chapters; the achievement is transformational in the sense that it puts major emphasis on research priorities from a “user” (decision-maker/manager, “demand-driven”) perspective, rather than the traditional predominantly “offer-driven” approach to research.
During this reporting period work continued with the Sub Projects seeking to implement EBM/EAF and in providing examples for enhance/alternative livelihood within the CLME+ region. Three of the outputs (3.1, 3.3 and 3.5) have been finalized under this outcome. The advances made under this outcome, means that 60% of the outputs have been delivered. Outputs 3.2 and 3.4 which commenced later than the other three are advancing, although some delays, accentuated as a result of COVID-19 pandemic, have been experienced.
It should be noted that unlike the other Components, all the outputs associated with Outcome 3 consisted of the development of their own project document and as such they are treated as sub projects within the wider CLME+ project. In light of this, progress under this Component will be reported on the output level.
Output 3.1 Well-planned, progressive transition to an ecosystem approach for the Caribbean spiny lobster fisheries This Output was successfully completed during this reporting period with the submission of the final report (Annex 21). Some of the main achievements outlined in the final report are summarized below: - Expansion of the stock evaluation as the basis for adjusting the regional regulation OS-02-09 with the support of the COPACO/OSPESCA/CRFM/CFMC Spiny Lobster Working Group(Annexes 40, 41, 43) . The interactive meetings of the IFCM proved essential to monitor the progress of the activities agreed towards improved regional governance of this fishery, considered one of the most valuable of the CLME+ region. - The spiny lobster fisheries management regional plan (MARPLESCA) (Annex 42) was finalized and formally adopted at the 17th Session of the WECAFC held in Miami, June, 2019 (Annex 4). This required previous approval from the OSPESCA Ministerial Council, the Joint Working Group, and the WECAFC Scientific Advisory Group. - An agreement about what kind data and formats will be used was achieved and integrated into MARPLESCA . A size-based stock assessment model was also agreed for future population assessments. (Annexes 47, 48, 49 and 50) - The existing Central America Fishing and Aquaculture Registering System (SIRPAC, in Spanish) for industrial and artisanal fishing boats was updated to version 2.0 (Annex 51) The registering systems for Colombia and Jamaica were also revised. A total of 67 fishing inspectors were trained and a pilot training in Guatemala took place(Annex 52) . Nicaragua fishing authority replaced its VMS system. - Supported the improvement and implementation of a standard for a fishing traceability system developed by OIRSA/OSPESCA (Annexes 44,45,46). The standard is being considered by their technical groups and a pilot in Honduras has taken place. - Development of indicators to measure the governance effectiveness to develop the base line and monitor its progress was accomplished with CERMES support (Annex 47).
Output 3.2 Well-planned, progressive transition to an ecosystem approach for the shrimp and groundfish (S&GF) fisheries of the NBSLME The following summarizes the achievements which have taken place under the Shrimp and Groundfish Sub Project till the end of June 2020. Many of the activities under this output are still being implemented with all technical work expected to be completed by December 2020 (Annex 22): - A training course in stock assessment for data limited situations took place in the Centro Nacional de Pesquisa e Conservacao da Biodiversidade Marinha do Nordeste (CEPENE) in collaboration with the Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, Recife, Brazil, in August 2019, with 21 participants working on pelagic and demersal fisheries of Northeast and North Brazil meeting report in preparation). - A Fisheries and Biological Data preparation workshop was held from 23-25 October 2018 in Barbados Annex 53). . Data availability by fishery and country was reviewed and discussed. A data collation template was reviewed and assessed by participants Annex 53). Marine resources and fisheries inventories for the FIRMS database were updated. - EAF training workshops were held in September 2019 in Suriname with 18 participants (Annex 54), Trinidad and Tobago with 44 participants (Annex 55) and Guyana with 39 participants (Annex 56). Four observers from the Guyana Fisheries Department received training in safety at sea in accordance with IMO standards. - The 3rd meeting of the WECAFC/CRFM/IFREMER Working Group on Shrimp and Groundfish of the Guianas-Brazil shelf took place in Paramaribo, Suriname, 26-27 November 2019(draft Report Annex 57). . The meeting brought together 25 participants including Working Group members, fisheries officers, fisherfolk representatives, academia, government organizations and FAO. Among other aspects, the WG was updated on the status and development of the national fisheries management plans, followed by the current status and necessary steps to develop the sub-regional EAF management plan for shrimp and groundfish. A work plan for the intersessional period was agreed upon by the participants (draft Report Annex 57). - National Inter-sectoral Committees (NICs) in Guyana, Suriname and Trinidad and Tobago were diagnosed, and assessed. Stakeholder interviews and workshops were held in Trinidad and Tobago, Guyana and Suriname. Workshop reports and NIC assessments per country were received in November 2019 (Report in Preparation). -National gender reports of the small scale shrimp and groundfish fisheries of Guyana (Annex 58), Suriname (Annex 59) and Trinidad and Tobago (Annex 60) were presented in November 2019. A sub-regional gender report was received in March 2020 and is currently under review (Annex 61).
Output 3.3 Well-planned, progressive transition to an ecosystem approach for the Eastern Caribbean flyingfish fisheries Work on this Sub Project is more or less finalised. A final draft Report (Annex 23) has been submitted. Below, we outline some of the achievements under this output defined in the final report: - Eastern Caribbean Flyingfish Fisheries Management Plan 2020-2025 (Annex 62) developed and discussed at the 3rd Meeting of the CRFM Ministerial Sub-Committee on Flyingfish Fishery in the Eastern Caribbean (MSCFF) (Annex 63); and, subsequently approved by the CRFM Ministerial Council (Annex 64). -The OECS Commission’s Ocean Governance Unit was a “target” of collaboration, given that Organisation’s development of the National (and Regional) “Ocean Governance Team” Mechanism. The subproject hosted meetings where stakeholders provided input and feedback on the partnership development process and other subproject outputs; including a special meeting of the WECAFC Working Group on Flyingfish (in October 2018) (Annex 65) and a regional consultation of flyingfish (in May 2019), as well as supporting the 3rd Meeting of the MSCFF (Annex 63). - Sub-regional data policy (Annex 62) approved by CRFM Ministerial Council and accepted it as a “base” data policy that could be used to inform development of other similar policies. - A link to the combined data and information repository for EAF management of Eastern Caribbean flyingfish (which will ultimately include identification and electronic consolidation of all published data and information) and online, keyword searchable, bibliographic database (with facility for download of published documents) is available on the CRFM website. (http://crfm.int click on: - Model national vessel licensing regulations formulated in the form of a model/harmonised flyingfish amendment to fisheries acts (Annexes 66 and 67) -Management recommendations to enhance livelihoods and human well-being (with due attention to gender equality and youth development issues) incorporated into ECFF-FMP 2020-2025 (Annex 62) -Value-chain problem solving - feasible options for added value, improved SPS and distribution and marketing identified for three countries participating in the fishery (Annex 68) - Compilation of Best Practices and Lessons Learnt (Annex 69)
Output 3.4 Demonstrating the transition to an Ecosystem-Based Management (EBM) approach at the sub-regional/site level in the CLME (Annex 70) Three countries are participating in the implementation under this sub project. Two have advanced significantly and one was starting implementation at the end of the reporting period (Annex 24). Notwithstanding all technical work on this output is expected to be completed by December 2020. The following summaries the status of the initiatives under this output: - Trinidad and Tobago: Institute of Marine Affairs (IMA) has been able to make significant progress with additional information from the Cunipia/Guayamare site/watersheds which feeds into the Carona River swamp (which was not originally considered as a baseline of nutrient pollution). Data from other projects (e.g. the Caroni River Basin Project) is also being incorporated to inform selected components of project activities and will be included as in-kind support. This has also resulted in some interesting preliminary findings e.g. data collected on water quality during the dry season in the latter part of the year has shown possible links to land based sources of pollution. DNA analysis of bacteria which has never been done for this habitat. Sampling to determine heavy metal concentrations in the blue land crab (Cardisoma guanhumi) which is harvested for human consumption was completed – results have been analysed and a report is underway. The study site has also been mapped using LiDAR digital elevation model and a questionnaire was developed to obtain information from farmers on practises regarding fertilizer type and usage. Stakeholder meetings have been held to share information on water quality and nutrient loading at sites in catchment areas of the watershed, and a socio-economic survey to gain knowledge on major crops, soil health, and pesticides is underway. Guyana: An inception planning meeting was held 11-12 June 2019 to formally engage implementing agencies and agree on actions to ensure project outcomes are achieved (Annex 71) – UNEP CEP participated virtually and provided opening remarks. Following an agreement with the University of Guyana, there are plans to conduct a community engagement exercise at the selected site (Wellington Park) in line with suspected pollution source/activity (sawmilling in Crabwood Creek). Suriname: There were a number of delays experienced with the start of the Suriname initiative which were exacerbated as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Notwithstanding by the end of this reporting period, work on the activities in Suriname had just commenced. Output 3.5 Modest small grants support for the implementation of C-SAP and/or P-SAP actions. Output successfully finalized. 1. T.P Target met. Two Small Grants which support the C-SAP implementation have been awarded to the Liamuiga Seamoss Group in St. Kitts and the Indian Castle Fisher Folk Association (ICFFA) in Nevis totaling US$52,820 to support projects that would demonstrate seamoss farming as a viable, alternative, livelihood in fishing communities. The Final Report was submitted during this reporting period. During this reporting period work advanced towards investments to reduce environmental stressors during the next decade.
Work under this component advanced during this reporting period with the completion of the Fisheries Investment Plans and work having commenced on the integrated pollution and habitats investment plans. A summary of advancements to date are summarized below: Output 4.1 (Pre-)feasibility reports on major investment needs and opportunities (see Output 4.2 comments) Output 4.2 Investment plans to deal with key issues identified under the CLME TDAs 1. T.PI1 The Cartagena Convention Secretariat has finalized a contract with The Ocean Foundation (TOF) (February 2020) (Annex 24) to simultaneously execute activities for both sub-programmes to develop: (1) the baseline/ (pre-)feasibility assessment reports for the enhanced protection and restoration of key habitats including through pollution prevention and mitigation, with special attention to coral reefs, seagrass beds and mangrove ecosystems and to pollution reduction from nutrients and sediments (at the time of reporting the Table of Contents and the Site Prioritization Scorecards for the Feasibility Report were available (Annexes 72 and 73)),, and 2) investments plan for integrated large-scale action on habitat protection and restoration and pollution reduction/mitigation in at least two priority hot spots, with special attention to habitats of critical economic importance in terms of current and potential future provisions of ecosystem goods & services (“blue growth”), and contributions to Global Environmental Benefits (GEBs). The integrated investment plans are expected to be developed by October 2020.

Target Met T.PI2 A letter of agreement (LoA) (Annex 74) with Conservation International was discussed and reviewed in late 2018, and signed in March 2019 to develop projects for Grenada and Guyana, as representative countries of the CLME and NBSLME, respectively. The projects in each country were developed so that they can be up-scaled to each of the LMEs they represent. The project in Grenada is focused on large pelagic species (Annex 26), while the project in Guyana is focused on shrimp and groundfish (Annex 27). A visit to Guyana took place in June 2019 for meeting with key stakeholders (fisher cooperatives, government agencies, NGOs, academia, fishing industry associations and fish wholesalers) (Annex 75). Subsequently, a rapid assessment of the Guyana artisanal groundfish fishery, based on Marine Stewardship Council (MSC) performance indicators, was prepared in order to present key information about the fishery and identify major deficiencies in ecological sustainability (Annex 76) . A stakeholder workshop was held in Guyana on 10-11 September 2019 in order to validate assessment results and present a draft business case for investing in Guyana’s artisanal finfish sector (Annex 77). . Results were presented in October 2019, reviewed and approved by FAO. FAO has submitted the Plans to both the Governments of Grenada and Guyana for their endorsement which is expected to obtain by September 2020. Ii) Milestone met – The CLME+ Hub www.clmeplus.org with relevant content and functionality online, to serve the purpose and goals of Regional Ocean Governance and the Coordination Mechanisms (knowledge management) by the end of the Project- The project proposed a transformational approach to knowledge management and information sharing, with special attention to the integration and sustainability of related efforts, and fully embracing the concept of the CLME+ SAP as an umbrella SAP (meaning that the SAP is a long-term programme, to be implemented collaborative by many organizations and through a multitude of projects): rather than exclusively focusing on a project website that would only be actively maintained for the duration of the project, CLME+ has put major focus on facilitating the development of a regional, long-term and collaborative “knowledge management and information sharing” platform, to be co-owned and populated by the many projects and organizations that contribute to the CLME+ SAP long term vision, and to be managed and maintained in time, by the Secretariat of the future long-term Ocean Governance Coordination Mechanism (providing also the opportunity for individual project websites to be easily linked to this central Hub): the “CLME+ Hub”, clmeplus.org is expected to contribute to a higher “return on investment” for all work on the marine environment, by facilitating enhanced coordination and collaboration, and better overall tracking and documenting of progress and success. The Hub also provides access to tools and databases developed under other activities/outputs of the CLME+ Project and other relevant SAP implementation projects. 2. T.PI2 Content developed & online for CLME+ SOMEE and SAP M&E web portal(s) and first SOMEE report (prototype/partial) launched by the end of project The approach identified and introduced by the CLME+ Project to the identification of desired content for SOMEE, and then the actual approach to developing CLME+ SOMEE content is seen as both highly innovative and transformational for the region as well as globally, as the work undertaken by the CLME+ Project: (a) aims to achieve long-term adoption of the GEF-supported TDA/SAP methodology by proposing its institutionalization through the CLME+ Regional Governance Framework (with a coordinating and contributing role for the secretariat of the ocean governance coordination mechanism (CM), and contributing roles – in alignment with existing institutional mandates and reporting obligations- for the CM membership); and (b) by proposing a major paradigm shift in the GEF IW community, revising and expanding the traditional GEF TDA focus from a problem-centered diagnosis to a diagnosis of both problems and opportunities (for sustainable blue socio-economic development) associated with the CLME+ marine resources, while also more strongly linking status of marine resources with status of governance processes. Work towards content development for the SOMEE approach has advanced along these innovative lines under this reporting period through the development of SOMEE “building blocks”, which include: - The State of the (Cartagena) Convention Area Report (SOCAR) with respect to land-based sources of pollution was endorsed by the 2019 Cartagena Convention IGM/COP (Annex 31) following review by the countries. - The final draft of the State of marine habitats report (SoMH) (Annex 32) developed by the Cartagena Convention Secretariat was submitted within the reporting period. - State of the Marine Environment and Associated Economies Report in the OECS Sub Region submitted within this reporting period (Annex 33) - Work is ongoing on the State of Fisheries Report by FAO and is expected to be finalized before the end of 2020. - the draft Spiny Lobster chapter has also been developed and shared with countries for their input (Annex 34) -a series of thematic maps (of which many are currently already hosted on caribbeanmarineatlas.net) Content for SOMEE still needs to be distilled form these building blocks, and further complemented with additional content, and will now gradually be brought online under the currently programmed SOMEE structure on the CLME+ Hub. Work on the SOMEE report is expected to resume during the coming weeks. The final version of the Mid Term Evaluation Report submitted in October 2018, indicated that despite having spent or transferred to partners 47% of the total budget, the project had only met a modest fraction of mid-term targets. The Mid-Term Evaluation Report went on to indicate that limited progress was specifically evident under Components 2 (providing policy tools) and 4 (catalyzing investments). The Mid-Term Evaluation Report also went on to state that an extension was necessary if several project outputs were to be successfully achieved. The initial findings of the Mid-Term Evaluation were taken to the Project Steering Committee (PSC) in June 2018. The PSC acknowledged the delay with Project activities and agreed to defer a decision related to an extension for the CLME+ Project until the first quarter of 2019. This proposal was made with the understanding that a further analysis of project implementation, until the end of 2018, would take place by the Project Coordination Unit (PCU). The results of this assessment were reviewed by the PSC in the first quarter of 2019. At the time of the assessment, 19 out of the 73 targets reviewed, excluding Component 3, had been partially or fully achieved leaving a total of 54 targets which still needed to be met, confirming continued delays with project implementation. Taking this into consideration, the PSC took the following decisions: - Approved a 12 month extension of the CLME+ Project, with a new end date of 30 April 2021 - Agreed to amendments of the Project Results Framework which reflected moderately reduced scope for some outputs and additional time to achieve Project Outputs & Outcomes - Agreed to the revision of the CLME+ Project budget which supports the implementation of the revised Results Framework and its new timeline - Agreed to increased reporting by co-executing partners on the status of their co-executing agreements - Urged co-executing partners to fulfill their committed objectives and use the monitoring tools developed by the PCU As of end of June 2019, 22 of the 73 milestones and targets assessed, excluding those under Component 3, were achieved or partially achieved. In relation to Outputs 3.1 and 3.3 under Component 3, the majority of the targets have been met as these outputs are expected to be completed by the end of 2019. Further, noticeable advancements have been observed with Output 3.2 which was delayed in commencing. The target associated with Output 3.5 has been successfully met with small grants given to two CSOs in St. Kitts and Nevis to support seamoss farming as an alternative livelihood in fishing communities and in support of the C-SAP. These and other achievements will be discussed in more detail below. Noting that the CLME+ PCU and PSC were able to adopt and implement adaptive management measures at an instrumental time during the project timeline, a positive tendency towards the achievement of the Development Objective is still anticipated.

T.PI1 The Regional Plan of Action to Prevent, Deter and Eliminate Illegal, Unregulated and Unreported Fishing in WECAFC Member Countries (2019 – 2029) was reviewed by the Joint CRFM/OSPESCA/WECAFC Working Group on IUU Fishing, the 10th Meeting of the Scientific Advisory Group of WECAFC in June 2019 and is expected to be presented to the 17 Session of WECAFC for their approval in July 2019. T.PI2 Preparation of the Regional Strategy and Action Plan for the Valuation, Protection and/or Restoration of Key Marine Habitats in the Wider Caribbean 2021 -2030 (RSAP) began in September 2018. Two consultation workshops have taken place to date. The first workshop was held on 3-4 December 2018 in Panama and involved 39 participants from 23 countries within the region. A follow-up workshop was held 13-14 March 2019 (Panama City, Panama) to produce a draft for presentation to the 10th SPAW COP (3 June 2019) in Roatán, Honduras. This draft RSAP was presented via the meeting document - Overview Report on the State of Marine Habitats in the Wider Caribbean & Regional Strategy and Action Plan for the Valuation, Protection and/or Restoration of Key Marine Habitats in the Wider Caribbean 2021 – 2030 and supported by SPAW COP10 Decision 14 for the Secretariat to continue “progress towards completing the draft State of Habitat and the 2020-2030 Regional Strategy and Action Plan and Investment Plan, ... for consideration at COP11 and further relevant action, taking into account the comments and inputs received by Parties and partners ...” It is anticipated that the document will be completed by end of 2019. 3. T.PI3 Teleconferences and meetings with various regional partners and the GEF CLME+ PCU were held to discuss the scope and content of the Regional Nutrients Strategy and Action Plan. Stemming from the one-day Technical Workshop on Pollution related matters held July 2018 in Panama City, A Regional Nutrients Strategy concept paper centred on the reduction of impacts from excess nutrient loads on priority marine ecosystems in the region was developed and endorsed by the 4th LBS STAC. Since then an updated concept paper was prepared (September 2018) which will be used as the basis to prepare the Regional Nutrients Strategy. The Regional Nutrients Strategy concept paper was endorsed at the 4th LBS COP and IGM held 4-5 June 2019. The final draft is expected to be completed adopted intersessionally by the end of 2019. Output 2.2 1. T.PI1 People Managing Oceans (The Civil Society Action Programme for the Sustainable Management for the Shared Living Marine Resources for the Caribbean and North Brazil Shelf Large Marine Ecosystems) has been developed and as of 30 June 2019, 35 Civil Society Organisations have endorsed the document, totally exceeding the target. The development of a version of the CLME+ SAP owned by civil society organizations is an innovative feature introduced by the CLME+ Project and is being globally acknowledged as “good practice” Target met 2. Civil Society Organisations have been engaged in a seamoss activity in St. Kitts and Nevis and a number of CSOs are also engaged in the North Brazil Shelf EMB sub project. Further FFOs have been engaged in all the Fisheries Sub-projects under component 3. Target met 3. T.PI3 A Donor Roundtable for Effective support for civil society and the Caribbean and North Brazil Shelf Large Marine Ecosystems was convened in March 2018. A Concept and Workplan for the development of a Small Grants Coordination Mechanism was developed and shared with the CLME+ PCU in August 2018. The concept was also discussed with donors who indicated interest in being part of the Small Grants Coordination Mechanism. Target partially met.
Output 2.3 1. T.PI1 A special session was included in the main agenda of the 2017 GCFI Annual Conference, where a selection of innovative technologies (relevant to Data & Information Management/DIM and Decision-Making/DM) were presented to the GCFI community. Technical briefs on these solutions were delivered by the presenters. Target met Output 2.4 T.PI1 First version of CLME+ Overarching Communications Strategy developed and available to all co-executing partners by end of 2016 Target met (Target B) Two Communication Specialists have resigned from the project since its inception resulting in a delay of work associated with this output. Notwithstanding, IW/LME LEARN provided resources to allow a consultant to undertake an assessment on “Supporting Knowledge Management (KM) and Communications activities in the GEF/UNDP CLME+ Project.” A number of recommendations made through the consultancy are being taken under consideration in revising the TORs for a Knowledge Management and Communications Specialist. The PCU has found its active participation in meetings of relevant partner IGO’s to be (among) the most effective means to enhance bi-directional communication on project matters with participating countries, on matters crossing several sectors with a stake in the marine environment. Output 2.5 1. T.PI1 (a)Technical Task Team Established. Milestone met as per the amended targets approved by Project Steering Committee (b) IOC of UNESCO and the University of Ghent have been working on an agreement to use a technological platform developed and supported by the latter as the means to link up stakeholders in need of training with those offering training opportunities. The “CLME+ training platform”, once developed, is to be linked with the CLME+ Hub Output 2.6 1. T.PI1 It was agreed that confusion may arise around the use of “Research Strategy” as the name for this output and therefore it was decided to use the term “Research Agenda”, which more accurately reflects the scope and intention of this output. It was also decided that the 3 topics would be integrated as different sections under a single “Research Strategy” document, the latter being more in line with the EBM approach. Three workshops to assess research needs for better decision-support on the three transboundary issues in greater detail have been conducted to date: 2016 in Grand Cayman (Pollution), 2017 in Merida, Mexico (Key Fisheries), and 2018 in San Andres, Colombia (Healthy marine habitats). The draft Pollution Section of the Research Agenda was reviewed at a meeting of the Project Executive Group in April 2018 and suggestions for revision of content made. Work on the other two elements of the Research Agenda is underway.
Two of the outputs (3.1 and 3.3) under this Outcome are to be finalized by the end of 2019 and as such most of the targets under these outputs have been achieved as has been outlined below. The two Outputs (3.2 and 3.4) which were delayed in implementation and commenced in 2018 have also advanced in the last 12 months as outlined below: Output 3.1 The following summarizes achievements that have taken place to date under the Spiny Lobster Fisheries Sub-Project: - OSPESCA convened an Inception Meeting in February 2017 with the sub-project participating countries (Bahamas, Belize, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Honduras, Jamaica, Nicaragua, and Panama). A workshop took place in June 2017 on the development and implementation of harmonized traceability systems for the spiny lobster fisheries. The system is under development and a potential adoption by the competent authorities is expected in 2019. - In November 2017 the sub-project countries met and agreed on the harmonization of data collection forms for Caribbean spiny lobster stock for assessment purposes and fisheries data such as landings, fishing effort, processing and export data. The forms are also included in the draft Regional Caribbean Spiny Lobster Fisheries Management Plan prepared in 2018. - In March 2018, the sub-project convened the second meeting of the OSPESCA/WECAFC/CRFM/CFMC Working Group on Caribbean Spiny Lobster where the traceability system and the management plan were presented. - The Spiny Lobster Management Plan was presented at the 9th session of the Scientific Advisory Group of the Western Central Atlantic Fisheries Commission (WECAFC) of the Food and Agriculture Organization in November 2018. The Management Plan is expected to be formally adopted at the 17th Meeting of the WECAFC in July 2019. - In 2018 the application of the Governance Effectiveness Assessment Framework (GEAF) was conducted for the period 2011-2015 with assistance from the Centre for Resource Management and Environmental Studies (CERMES) of the University of the West Indies (UWI). The results showed that OSPESCA is the organization with better application of the policy cycle due to the integration promoted and legal framework developed in the Central America Integration System (SICA). For example, the harmonized 4-months- regional closed season is implemented simultaneously in all SICA countries. - In 2018, additional financing resources were mobilized to leverage sub-project activities in the second semester of 2018 and in 2019. Funds were provided by the US Department of State through the ResCA project (Resilient Central America) executed by The Nature Conservancy (TNC). The total amount is US $ 200,000. - The Ecolangosta+ sub-project prepared a draft version of the Caribbean Spiny Lobster fisheries subchapter to be incorporated into the SOMEE Report. This document is expected to become a prototype to be used as an example to be followed by other organizations when preparing their respective materials on fisheries and the environment. Output 3.2 The following summarizes the advancements with this output within the last 12 months: - Two meetings of the CRFM/IFREMER/WECAFC Working Group on Shrimp and Groundfish of the Guianas-Brazil shelf have taken place. The Working Group Recommendation WECAFC/17/2019/5 “On the Management of Shrimp and Groundfish Resources of the North Brazil-Guianas Shelf in the WECAFC Area” will be presented for endorsement at the 17th Session of WECAFC in Miami, 15-18 July 2019. - The Regional Data Collection and Reporting Framework (DCRF), prepared by the Working Group on Fisheries Data and Statistics (FDS-WG), was presented and discussed at the Data Preparation Workshop on Shrimp and Groundfish of the NBSLME which took place in Barbados, 23-25 October 2018. Statistical and biological information on key species and fisheries for the NBSLME is being collated at the country level for inclusion into a sub-regional data policy framework. - A Fisheries and Biological Data preparation workshop was held from 23-25 October 2018 in Barbados. Data availability by fishery and country was reviewed and discussed. A data collation template was reviewed and assessed by participants. Marine resources and fisheries inventories for the FIRMS database were updated. - A Regional Plan of Action against IUU has been prepared through a collaborative and consultative process and will be presented at the 17th Session of WECAFC, to be held in Miami from 15-18 July 2019, for endorsement by the Commission. Once endorsed, the RPOA-IUU will provide the template and guidelines for development of National Plans of Action against IUU (NPOA-IUU). - An EAF training workshop was held in Brasilia, Brazil, from 26-30 November, 2018 in collaboration with the REBYC II LAC Project. A course in stock assessment for data limited situations took place from 21-25 January 2019 in Port of Spain, Trinidad, with participants from Brazil, French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname, and Trinidad and Tobago. - Sub-regional and National EAF management plans are under development to include, among others, long-term access to sustainable fisheries resources for local fishers. - A Letter of Agreement (LoA) with CERMES has been signed in February 2019. Work to be undertaken includes gender analyses for shrimp and groundfish fisheries in Guyana, Suriname and Trinidad and Tobago, and the preparation of a sub-regional report on gender for the NBSLME. National consultants have been hired in Guyana, Suriname and Trinidad and Tobago for review of existing information on gender, field work, stakeholder consultations and preparation of national reports. In Suriname coordination is underway with the REBYC II LAC project regarding an ongoing gender study of the industrial trawl fishery. National gender reports should be finalized by August 2019.
Output 3.3 The following summarizes achievements that have taken place to date under the Flyingfish Fisheries Sub-Project: - Draft Cooperation agreement between the Government of France and CFRM has been developed and endorsed by 17th Meeting of the Caribbean Fisheries Forum (CFF 17) and the 3rd Meeting of the CRFM Ministerial Sub-Committee on Flyingfish (MSCFF3). MSCFF3 also endorsed a process going forward toward negotiation, finalisation and ultimately signing of the draft Cooperation Agreement. - Draft Regional Data Policy was developed and presented at a Special Meeting of WECAFC Working Group on Flyingfish in October 2018. Based on these inputs the draft policy was further revised and presented to CFF 17, which gave its endorsement of the policy and which was presented to MSCFF3 which has also endorsed the Policy. - Evaluation of several data management portal/systems which could be appropriate for CRFM Member State requirements undertaken. Compiled FAO, FIRMS and FIGIS documentation and started to extract the information about metadata, standards and the typical functions required by the FAO in terms of data management policy. Consultancy website completed: - Communication Strategy and Action Plan drafted; Stakeholder identification and analysis of key regional and selected national stakeholders has been updated. Initial Knowledge Attitude Practice (KAP) and final studies have been completed and results endorsed by the 17 Caribbean Fisheries Forum and 3rd Meeting of the CRFM Ministerial Sub-Committee on Flyingfish. - Guide for review of monitoring and evaluation of the 2014 Eastern Caribbean Flyingfish Fishery Management Plan (ECFF-FMP) developed and reviewed. Based on that evaluation, recommendations for updating the ECFF-FMP have been made and incorporated/taken into consideration in updating and production of ECFF FMP 2020-2025 - Recommendations for enhancing livelihoods and human well-being, with attention to gender equality and youth development issues, have been incorporated into the ECFF—FMP; a report on gender related issues in the fishery is currently being finalised - Draft impact assessment tool developed and reviewed for FMP Implementation and Support. FMP Evaluation Report and Sub-Project After-Life Plan have been prepared and endorsed by CFF 17 and MSCFF3. - Additional funds have been received by the Canadian government to support work on gender under this output. The proposed concept outlining the activities which will supplement work under this output was approved by the Canadian government in June 2019. Output 3.4 The following summaries key advancements under this output within the last 12 months: 3. T.SRI1 Small Scale Funding Agreements to support the implementation of activities associated with the North Brazil Shelf EBM Sub Project at the country level have been finalized between UN Environment Caribbean Environment Programme and the Governments of Trinidad and Tobago, Suriname and Guyana. Although numerous efforts were made to engage Brazil in this sub-project, no agreement was finalized to date. Due to the fact that timely implementation of project activities does not seem feasible at this point consideration will be given for re-allocation to other activities. Based on discussions with Government partners in Guyana and Trinidad & Tobago in early February 2019, the completion of all activities is still expected to be completed by December 2019 with first progress reports received in June 2019. Due to the fact that the agreement with Suriname was only finalised in early 2019, they have indicated an end date for project activities to be June 2020.
Output 3.5 1. T.PI1 Two Small Grants which support the C-SAP implementation have been awarded to the Liamuiga Seamoss Group in St. Kitts and the Indian Castle Fisher Folk Association (ICFFA) in Nevis totaling US$52,820 to support projects that would demonstrate seamoss farming as a viable, alternative, livelihood in fishing communities. Target met Advancements under this outcome have been delayed. This is due to the fact that commencement of the activities under this outcome are dependent on the successful completion of activities under Output 2.1. Notwithstanding, the 12 month extension approved by the CLME+ Project Steering Committee has allowed for additional time to successfully implement this outcome. A summary of advancements to date are summarized below: Output 4.1 (see Output 4.2 comments) Output 4.2 1. T.PI1 Investment plans have to be based on the relevant outputs linked to pollution reduction and habitat restoration. This will be further linked to the CEP Strategy and Resource Mobilization Strategy and ongoing project proposals being developed by the Secretariat to address pollution reduction and habitat restoration An opportunity has been identified to link this activity with ongoing work by UN Environment for Green Climate Funding, as well as the preparation of a new GEF Project for the Amazon focusing on the implementation of their Strategic Action Programme. The development of a new joint IDB/UN Environment proposal on wastewater (GEF CReW+) is also expected to directly support this activity which is expected to be a major focus area in 2019. In 2015, CLME+ co-executing partner, FAO, held a workshop with IDB to identify investment needs for the fisheries in the NBSLME http://www.fao.org/3/a-i5648e.pdf. A letter of agreement (LoA) between FAO and Conservation International was signed in March 2019. Conservation International will develop fisheries related investment projects for Grenada and Guyana, as representative countries of the CLME and NBSLME, respectively. The projects in each country will be developed so they can be up-scaled to each of the LMEs they represent. The project in Grenada will be focused on large pelagic species, while the project in Guyana will be focused on shrimp and groundfish. The work team has been identified and the work plan has been cleared.
Progress under this outcome has continued with 47% of milestones and targets being partially achieved or fully achieved. Other milestones and targets are on target to be successfully achieved: 1. TPI.1 Nineteen countries have signed the CLME+ Project Document and CLME+ SAP endorsement now covers 26 countries and 8 overseas territories. Further nineteen countries have nominated CLME+ Project National Focal Points. Many countries are participating in regional projects that support CLME+ SAP and Project implementation. Seventeen countries were represented at the Mid-Term Project Steering Committee which took place 18-20 June 2018 Target met 2. T.PI2 Eight overseas territories have endorsed the CLME+ SAP. Whilst GEF resources cannot be directed to overseas territories, a number of territories who are members of inter-governmental organisations are supporting CLME+ SAP implementation through a number of activities, such as the development of fishery management plans, IUU RPOA, State of Convention Report, establishment of National Intersectoral Coordination Mechanisms, etc. Target met 3. TPI3 Project Co-executing agreements have been finalized with all nine of the co-executing partners assisting with the implementation of the CLME+ Project activities. The partners include: UNESCO-IOC, FAO, OSPESCA, CRFM, OECS Commission, UNEP, CANARI, GCFI and UWI-CERMES. The Caribbean Community and the Caribbean Sea Commission of the Association of Caribbean States, UN ECLAC and a number of other prospective partners including The Nature Conservancy, Conservation International, the Caribbean Biodiversity Fund, the Caribbean Biological Corridor and the Commonwealth submitted Letters of Intent or otherwise expressed interest in partnering with the CLME+ Project on SAP implementation. The first CLME+ Partnership Forum is expected to take place in September 2019 where interested partners will be asked to formally join the Partnership. Target met 4. T.PI3 Twenty-eight Civil Society Organisations have endorsed the C-SAP which supports CLME+ SAP implementation. Target partially met 5. T.PI4 Regional Projects being implemented within the CLME+ region that are supportive of the CLME+ Strategic Action Programme include, e.g.: - Caribbean Marine Atlas, Phase 2 - Caribbean Regional Oceanscape Project (CROP) - Developing Organizational Capacity for Ecosystem Stewardship and Livelihoods in Caribbean Small Scale Fisheries (StewardFish) - Caribbean Billfish Project - Integrated Transboundary Ridge to Reef Management of the Mesoamerican Reef (MAR2R) The “PPI” database is accessible through the CLME+ Hub https://clmeplus.org/ppi-search/ Milestone met 6. T.PI5 Wide-ranging political endorsement of the SAP by CLME+ countries has facilitated the leveraging of additional resources, from the GEF and more recently from the Canadian government, for (coordinated) SAP implementation. Precise data are currently lacking to adequately assess progress towards this Milestone and Targets, but it can reasonably be assumed from e.g. the content of the Programmes Projects-and-Initiatives (PPI) database and from the Featured Projects section on the CLME+ Hub (www.clmeplus.org) that the milestone is met/exceeded, and that the end target will be achieved Milestone partially met Output 5.2 T.PI1 Building off of information obtained during the February 2018 “CLME+ SAP Monitoring & Evaluation Workshop ” (including the methodological sheets) the CLME+ PCU is continuing to work with SAP Strategy leads along with other key SAP Strategy individuals to finalize the steps to implement each SAP action, which will facilitate the identification of appropriate and relevant objectives and thus better-defined indicators. The information generated by this process will be managed using adaptive management software which will provide internal models and a database for storing and internal assessment of indicator metadata and values. Externally, this information will be visualized through an online dashboard like action implementation tracking tool. This process is being carried out in phases with the spiny lobster strategy being completed ahead of the others. A terms of reference for this work has been prepared and will be posted mid 2019 in order to bring on a consultant to assist in building out the online SAP action implementation tracking tool. Target partially met 2. T.PI2 (a) Progress continued with the State of Marine Environment and associated Economies (SOMEE) Report in the last 12 months. The SOMEE outline and approach has been endorsed by the constituents of the following ICM members: UN Environment CEP, WECAFC-FAO, IOCARIBE, OSPESCA, CCAD, CRFM and OECS. Target met In early 2019, the PCU undertook a scoping exercise and agreed that the initial focus of SOMEE will be chapters 1, chapter 2 (fisheries overview), and subchapter 3.2.1 (EAF for spiny lobster fisheries). It was also decided that the spiny lobster subchapter would be developed first, as a prototype of the SOMEE approach and an example for development of the other fisheries subchapters. (b) The structure for the online version of SOMEE and SAP M&E Frameworks are scheduled to be developed starting in July and September 2019 respectively. A procurement processes for associated services has been initiated in Q2 of 2019. Output 5.3 1. T.PI1 A basic CLME+ Project website with basic content and functionality was developed and available in English and Spanish by the first quarter of 2017. The CLME+ Project website was embedded in/linked to an over-arching online hub, the “CLME+ Hub” (www.clmeplus.org), which aims at bringing together, and sharing information relative to the SAP among the members of the CLME+ Partnership. The Hub also aims to provide access to tools and databases developed under other activities/outputs of the CLME+ and other relevant SAP implementation projects. Link with Caribbean Marine Atlas 2. Milestone met 2. T.PI2 There have also been advances with other State of Reports which are expected to contribute to SOMEE: - The State of the (Cartagena) Convention Area Report (SOCAR) with respect to land-based sources of pollution: Developed by UNEP CEP with financial support from the CLME+ Project and others. The draft report was endorsed by the 2019 Cartagena Convention IGM/COP, following review by the countries and is expected to be integrated into SOMEE. - The State of marine habitats report (SoMH): Being led by UNEP CEP (with financial support from the CLME+ Project). Two drafts of the document had been prepared and comments from the PCU and countries have been shared with CEP for their input. It is anticipated that the document will be finalised by end of 2019. - The FAO WECAFC State of fisheries and aquaculture (SOFIA): FAO has prepared a regional WECAFC SOFIA for WECAFC17. The fisheries overview will follow the SOMEE approach and build on the SOFIA content. - the draft Spiny Lobster chapter has also been developed and shared with countries for their input Content is not yet online for either CLME+ SOMEE or SAP M&E, but the content is scheduled to placed online in July and September respectively.

The first CLME+ Partnership Forum is scheduled to take place in September 2019 in collaboration with 21 LME COP. Milestone partially met; on track to be fully met 4.
